title-group.article-title: Analysis of PSLQ, An Integer Relation Finding Algorithm

abstract.p: Let K be either the real, complex, or quaternion number system and let O(K) be the corresponding integers. Let x = (x<sub>1</sub>,..., x<sub>n</sub>) be a vector in K<sup>n</sup>. The vector x has an integer relation if there exists a vector m = (m<sub>1</sub>,..., m<sub>n</sub>) ∈ O(K)<sup>n</sup>, m ≠ 0, such that <tex-math>$m_1 x_1 + m_2 x_2 +... + m_nx_n = 0$</tex-math>. In this paper we define the parameterized integer relation construction algorithm PSLQ(τ), where the parameter τ can be freely chosen in a certain interval. Beginning with an arbitrary vector x = (x<sub>1</sub>, ⋯, x<sub>n</sub>) ∈ K<sup>n</sup>, iterations of PSLQ(τ) will produce lower bounds on the norm of any possible relation for x. Thus PSLQ(τ) can be used to prove that there are no relations for x of norm less than a given size. Let M<sub>x</sub> be the smallest norm of any relation for x. For the real and complex case and each fixed parameter τ in a certain interval, we prove that PSLQ(τ) constructs a relation in less than O(n<sup>3</sup> + n<sup>2</sup> log M<sub>x</sub>) iterations.
